{{Redirect|Turkey tail|the tail of a turkey|Pygostyle}} {{Stack | {{Taxobox | image = Trametes versicolor G4 (1).JPG | image_width = 234px | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Polyporales]] | familia = [[Polyporaceae]] | genus = ''[[Trametes]]'' | species = '''''T. versicolor''''' | binomial = ''Trametes versicolor'' | binomial_authority = ([[L.]]) [[Curtis Gates Lloyd|Lloyd]] (1920) | synonyms = ''Boletus versicolor'' L. (1753)
''Polyporus versicolor'' (L.) [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]] (1821)
''Coriolus versicolor'' (L.) [[Quél.]] (1886) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Trametes versicolor'' | hymeniumType=pores | capShape = offset | capShape2 = no | whichGills = decurrent | stipeCharacter=NA | sporePrintColor=white | sporePrintColor2=yellow | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | howEdible=unpalatable}} }} '''''Trametes versicolor''''' – also known as ''Coriolus versicolor'' and ''Polyporus versicolor'' – is a common [[polypore]] [[mushroom]] found throughout the world. Meaning 'of several colours', ''versicolor'' reliably describes this fungus that displays different colors. For example, because its shape and multiple colors are similar to those of a [[wild turkey]], ''T. versicolor'' is commonly called '''turkey tail'''. ==Description and ecology== The top surface of the cap shows typical concentric zones of different colours. The flesh is 1–3 mm thick and has leathery texture. Older specimens, such as the one pictured, can have zones with green algae growing on them, thus appearing green. It commonly grows in tiled layers. The cap is rust-brown or darker brown, sometimes with blackish zones. The cap is flat, up to 8 x 5 x 0.5–1 cm in area. It is often triangular or round, with zones of fine hairs. The pore surface is whitish to light brown, pores round and with age twisted and labyrinthine. 3-8 pores per millimeter. It may be eaten by [[caterpillar]]s of the [[fungus moth]] ''[[Nemaxera betulinella]]'' and by [[maggots]] of the [[Platypezidae|Platypezid]] fly ''Polyporivora picta''.{{Citation|last=Chandler|first=Peter J.|title=The Flat-footed flies (Opetiidae and Platypezidae) of Europe|series=[[Fauna Entomologica Scandinavica]]|volume=36|date=2001|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|isbn=90-04-12023-8|pages=1–278}} and the fungus gnat ''[[Mycetophila luctuosa]]'' Jakovlev, J. 2011: Fungus gnats (Diptera: Sciaroidea) associated with dead wood and wood growing fungi: new rearing data from Finland and Russian Karelia and general analysis of known larval microhabitats in Europe.'' Entomol. Fennica'' 22: 157–189. [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/279468561_Fungus_gnats_Diptera_Sciaroidea_associated_with_dead_wood_and_wood_growing_fungi_New_rearing_data_from_Finland_and_Russian_Karelia_and_general_analysis_of_known_larval_microhabitats_in_Europe pdf] ==Chemistry== ''T. versicolor'' contains [[polysaccharide]]s under [[basic research]], including the protein-bound PSP and β-1,3 and β-1,4 [[glucans]]. The lipid fraction contains the lanostane-type tetracyclic triterpenoid sterol ergosta-7,22,dien-3β-ol as well as fungisterol and β-sitosterol.{{cite journal|last1=Yokoyama|first1=A|title=Distribution of tetracyclic triterpenoids of lanostane group and sterols in higher fungi especially of the polyporacea and related families|journal=Phytochemistry|date=1975|volume=14|issue=2|pages=487–497|doi=10.1016/0031-9422(75)85115-6}}{{cite journal|last1=Endo|first1=S|title=Lipids of five species of polyporacea|journal=Tokyo Gakugei|date=1981|volume=16}} ==Research and uses== This mushroom, known as ''yun zhi'' [雲芝] in China, is used in traditional Chinese medicine; it is supposed to boost the immune system and have anticarcinogenic properties. Its polysaccharides are thought to be the effective constituents. {{Main|Polysaccharide-K}} [[Clinical trial]]s in people with [[breast cancer]], [[leukemias]], and [[liver cancer]] remain inconclusive as of 2016.{{cite web | url=https://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/integrative-medicine/herbs/coriolus-versicolor | title=Coriolus versicolor | publisher=Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY | date=2016 | accessdate=20 October 2016}} ==Gallery== Image:Schmetterlingstramete_Trametes_versicolor_001.jpg|''T. versicolor'' covering a stump Image:Schmetterlingstramete Trametes versicolor 004.jpg|Close up of ''T. versicolor''. Image:Trametes_versicolor_2.jpg|Color variation of ''T. versicolor'' on the same tree stump Image:Trametes.versicolor4.-.lindsey.jpg|Pale specimens Image:Schmetterlingstramete_(Trametes_versicolor)_-_hms(1).jpg| Brown variety Image:Trametes_versicolor_different_colours.jpg| Pale and brown varieties side by side ==See also== {{Portal|Fungi}} *[[Forest pathology]] *[[List of Trametes species|List of ''Trametes'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons}} * [http://mushroom-collecting.com/mushroomturkey.html Mushroom-Collecting.com – Trametes versicolor] {{Taxonbar|from=Q753833|authorityControlTaxon}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Trametes Versicolor}} [[Category:Polyporaceae]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1753]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Inedible fungi]] [[Category:Medicinal fungi]] [[Category:Taxa named by Carl Linnaeus]]
